title: Historical Volatility
notes: This equation calculates historical volatility from price data. sigma_hist represents the historical volatility

title: Exponentially Weighted Moving Average
notes: This equation defines the EWMA volatility model. sigma_EWMA represents the EWMA volatility estimate

notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: GARCH(p

title: EGARCH Model
equation_latex: ln(sigma_{t}^{2}) = \text{omega} + alpha \times (|epsilon_{t-1}| / sigma_{t-1} - sqrt(2/pi)) + gamma \times (epsilon_{t-1} / sigma_{t-1}) + beta \times ln(sigma_{t-1}^{2})
notes: This equation defines the EGARCH model

title: GJR-GARCH Model
equation_latex: sigma_{t}^{2} = \text{omega} + alpha \times epsilon_{t-1}^{2} + gamma \times epsilon_{t-1}^{2} \times I \times (epsilon_{t-1} < 0) + beta \times sigma_{t-1}^{2}
notes: This equation defines the GJR-GARCH model

title: Stochastic Volatility Model
equation_latex: dS_{t} = \text{mu} \times S_{t} \times dt + sqrt(v_{t}) \times S_{t} \times dW_{t}^{S}
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: Heston Correlation
notes: This equation defines the correlation between asset price and volatility shocks in the Heston model. rho represents the correlation coefficient

title: Heston Characteristic Function
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: SABR Model
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: SABR Implied Volatility
equation_latex: sigma_{BSM}(K) = (alpha / (F^{1-beta})) \times (z / x \times (z)) \times (1 + ((1-beta)^{2} \times alpha^{2} / (24 \times F^{2-2beta}) + rho \times beta \times nu \times alpha / (4 \times F^{1-beta}) + (2 - 3 \times rho^{2}) \times nu^{2} / 24) \times T)
notes: This equation gives the implied volatility under the SABR model. sigma_BSM represents the Black-Scholes implied volatility

title: Dupire Formula
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: Poisson Process
notes: This equation defines the Poisson process for jump arrivals. N_t represents the number of jumps by time t

title: Poisson Process Probability
equation_latex: P \times (N_{t} = n) = exp(-lambda \times t) \times (lambda \times t)^{n} / n!
notes: This equation gives the probability of n jumps occurring by time t. The Poisson distribution has mean lambda * t and variance lambda * t. The Poisson process is the standard model for discrete events like defaults or jumps in asset prices.

title: Compound Poisson Process
notes: This equation defines the compound Poisson process. X_t represents the accumulated jump size

title: Jump-Diffusion Model
equation_latex: dS_{t} = \text{mu} \times S_{t} \times dt + \text{sigma} \times S_{t} \times dW_{t} + S_{t} \times dJ_{t}
notes: This equation defines the Merton jump-diffusion model. dS_t is the asset price change

title: Jump Component
notes: This equation defines the jump component in the jump-diffusion model. Y is the log jump size (typically normal)

title: Merton Jump-Diffusion Solution
equation_latex: S_{t} = S_{0} \times exp((\text{mu} - 0.5 \times \text{sigma}^{2} - lambda \times (exp(mu_{J} + 0.5 \times sigma_{J}^{2}) - 1)) \times t + \text{sigma} \times W_{t} + sum_{i=1}^{N_{t}} Y_{i})
notes: This equation gives the solution to the Merton jump-diffusion SDE. S_t represents the asset price

title: Kou Double Exponential Jump Model
notes: This equation defines the Kou double exponential jump size distribution. Y_i represents the log jump size

title: Variance Gamma Process
notes: This equation defines the Variance Gamma (VG) process. X_t represents the log return

title: CGMY Process
notes: G * G_t))

title: Lévy Process
notes: This equation defines a general Lévy process. X_t represents the process value

title: Lévy Measure
notes: This equation defines the Lévy measure for jump processes. nu(dx) represents the intensity of jumps of size dx

title: Characteristic Function of Lévy Process
equation_latex: phi(u) = exp(i \times u \times \text{mu} \times t - 0.5 \times \text{sigma}^{2} \times u^{2} \times t + t \times integral_{R} (exp(i \times u \times x) - 1 - i \times u \times x \times I(|x| < 1)) \times nu(dx))
notes: This equation defines the characteristic function of a Lévy process. phi(u) represents the characteristic function

title: Fourier Transform Option Pricing
equation_latex: C = exp(-r \times T) \times (1/2pi) \times integral_{i \times infinity}^{-i \times infinity} exp(-i \times u \times ln(K)) \times psi(u) / (i \times u) du
notes: This equation defines option pricing using Fourier transform methods. C represents the call option price

title: Super-Replication Price
notes: This equation defines the super-replication price. V_super represents the minimum cost of a hedging strategy that dominates the payoff under all scenarios. In incomplete markets

title: Sub-Replication Price
notes: This equation defines the sub-replication price. V_sub represents the maximum value of a hedging strategy that is dominated by the payoff under all scenarios. Sub-replication provides a lower bound on the option price.

title: No-Arbitrage Price Interval
notes: This equation defines the no-arbitrage price interval in incomplete markets. The market price must lie between the sub-replication and super-replication prices. This interval can be wide in highly incomplete markets

title: Utility-Based Pricing
notes: This equation defines utility-based pricing. V represents the value maximizing expected utility U of consumption

title: Indifference Pricing
equation_latex: Indifference Price = E[U \times (W + payoff - price)] - E[U \times (W)]
notes: This equation defines the indifference price. The indifference price is the amount that makes the investor indifferent between holding the derivative and not holding it. Indifference pricing depends on the investor's utility function U and initial wealth W.

title: Entropy Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines the entropic risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk-adjusted value of the random payoff X

title: Convex Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines a convex risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk measure

title: Robust Optimization
notes: Advanced Topics - Incomplete Markets

title: Ambiguity Aversion
equation_latex: V = inf_{Q in Q} E_{Q}[payoff] + phi(Q)
notes: This equation defines pricing under model uncertainty (ambiguity aversion). V represents the value

title: Good-Deal Bounds
notes: This equation defines the good-deal bounds on the market price of risk theta. The bounds restrict the set of equivalent martingale measures to those that are not too extreme. Good-deal bounds narrow the no-arbitrage price interval by excluding unrealistic pricing measures.

title: Minimal Martingale Measure
notes: This equation defines the minimal martingale measure. The minimal martingale measure is the equivalent martingale measure that is closest to the physical measure in terms of relative entropy. It is used when the market price of risk is not uniquely defined.

title: Föllmer-Schweizer Decomposition
notes: This equation defines the Föllmer-Schweizer decomposition. X_t represents the discounted payoff

title: Mean-Variance Hedging
notes: This equation defines mean-variance hedging. The objective is to minimize the mean-squared hedging error between the payoff and the hedge portfolio. Mean-variance hedging is the optimal quadratic hedging strategy in incomplete markets.

title: Quadratic Hedging
notes: This equation defines quadratic hedging with a traded asset S_t and a residual value V_t. The hedge portfolio minimizes the mean-squared hedging error. Quadratic hedging is widely used when perfect hedging is impossible.

title: Market Price of Model Risk
notes: This equation defines the market price of model risk. lambda_model represents the Sharpe ratio of model risk

title: Model Uncertainty
notes: This equation incorporates model risk into pricing. V represents the risk-adjusted value

title: Deep Hedging
notes: This equation defines deep hedging using neural networks. Hedge_theta represents the hedging strategy parameterized by theta
